title: Wall Street Extends Gains on Fed Rate-Cut Bets
details: Wall Street's main indexes rose for a fourth consecutive session on Wednesday, as investors parsed fresh economic data while expecting a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in December. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.6%, the S&P 500 rose 0.58%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.71%. These gains were driven by falling jobless claims and rising core capital goods orders, boosting rate-cut probabilities to 84.9%. However, this optimism masks inefficiencies in monetary policy reliance, highlighting hypocrisies where tariff-induced volatility undermines economic self-reliance and national sovereignty by amplifying external dependencies on global trade dynamics.

title: Kremlin Confirms Preliminary Agreement for Witkoff's Moscow Visit on Ukraine Peace
details: Kremlin aide Yury Ushakov confirmed a preliminary agreement for U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff, possibly with Jared Kushner, to visit Moscow next week for Ukraine-Russia peace discussions, including a meeting with Putin. This follows a leaked call where Witkoff advised on presenting Russia's plan to Trump, which Trump described as standard negotiation to balance interests between Ukraine and Russia. The White House push has led to revised 19-point peace terms agreed by Ukraine in Geneva talks, with minor details pending and European involvement in security guarantees.

title: Trump Rages at NYT Over Age and Health Hit Piece
details: President Donald Trump, aged 79 and the oldest ever elected to the Oval Office, lashed out on Truth Social at a New York Times story highlighting his advanced age, reduced public events compared to his first term, shorter schedules from noon to 5 p.m., and instances like nodding off in the Oval Office plus a recent MRI scan. He boasted of a perfect physical exam and aced comprehensive cognitive test, accusing the Times of unfair, negative coverage amid his ongoing feud, including a dismissed $15 billion lawsuit claiming it's a Democrat mouthpiece. The Times defended its accurate, firsthand reporting and vowed to continue despite intimidation. This episode underscores inefficiencies in executive self-reliance, as Trump's reliance on social media rants over substantive health transparency reveals hypocrisies in dismissing media scrutiny while suing it, potentially eroding public trust in leadership sovereignty without addressing age-related governance impacts.

title: Trump Delivered on Deregulation, Not Oil Boom
details: Trump pledged rapid oil and gas expansion upon taking office, ordering the administration to access vast U.S. petroleum reserves. Nearly a year later, fossil fuel production remains near Biden-era record levels, with increases driven by efficiency gains rather than new drilling. Oil prices have fallen from $75 to below $60 per barrel, but pump prices dipped only briefly, not halving as promised, while tariffs raised steel costs for oil equipment.

title: U.N. Report: Gaza War Reconstruction Costs Over $70 Billion
details: The United Nations reports that Israel's war on Gaza has caused an 87% economic contraction from 2023 to 2024, reducing GDP per capita to $161, one of the world's lowest, and will require over $70 billion for reconstruction over decades amid repeated ceasefire violations that killed at least 342 Palestinians since October 10. A German study estimates the death toll exceeds 100,000, far above the Palestinian Health Ministry's 69,733, with life expectancy dropping 44% in 2023 and 47% in 2024, equivalent to 34-36 years lost. Heavy rains exacerbate the crisis for 2 million displaced residents in tents without sewage, leading to overflowing cesspits and disease outbreaks. This devastation highlights inefficiencies in international aid and ceasefires, exposing hypocrisies in global powers' sovereignty claims while fostering dependency and undermining self-reliance in Gaza's recovery.

title: DOJ Charges Against Comey and James Dismissed
details: A federal judge dismissed DOJ charges against former FBI Director James Comey (lying to Congress and obstructing proceedings related to 2020 statements on Clinton email probe) and New York AG Letitia James due to the unlawful appointment of interim US Attorney Lindsey Halligan under federal statutes. The ruling, a technical decision on appointment procedures, undid the indictments presented by Halligan, appointed by AG Pam Bondi amid Trump prodding; Comey's case hit a five-year statute deadline, while James's did not. Comey called it a reflection of DOJ's malevolence under Trump, highlighting White House interference via public statements from Press Secretary Leavitt and Bondi, who plan appeals. This exposes inefficiencies in politicized prosecutions, undermining judicial sovereignty and self-reliant enforcement by prioritizing personal vendettas over legal independence, with potential for re-indictments straining resources.

title: Latest US-Ukraine Peace Plan Revisions After Geneva Talks
details: The US revised its initial 28-point Russia-Ukraine peace plan to a 19-point version following Geneva talks with Ukrainian officials, removing the 600,000-troop cap on Ukraine's military and adjusting amnesty provisions to address war victims' grievances, while leaving territorial concessions and NATO membership for presidential decisions. This comes amid European criticism of the original plan as a capitulation rewarding Russia's invasion, with allies proposing alternatives like NATO access for Ukraine and a higher 800,000-troop limit. Russia remains unhappy with changes reducing its territorial gains, highlighting inefficiencies in US-led diplomacy that sidelines Europe and Ukraine initially, potentially undermining sovereignty by forcing concessions without broad consensus and risking future conflicts through unaddressed Russian demands.

title: Former Ambassador Reflects on Ukraine-Russia Peace Efforts
details: The Trump administration is pushing for a peace deal to end the Russia-Ukraine war, with special envoy Steve Witkoff scheduled to visit Moscow next week. This follows Bloomberg News reports of an October phone transcript showing Witkoff advising a Putin advisor on pitching a peace plan to President Trump. Here & Now host Scott Tong speaks with former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine William Taylor about these developments.

title: Democrats Push Back on FBI Probe into Lawmakers' Video
details: The Trump administration launched an FBI investigation into six Democratic lawmakers with national security backgrounds after they posted a video on X advising military members to refuse illegal orders, prompting outreach from the FBI's counterterrorism division. The lawmakers, including Sen. Mark Kelly and Rep. Jason Crow, issued a joint statement rejecting intimidation and affirming their constitutional duties, while some Republicans like Sens.

title: Lawmaker: Transcript Indicates Witkoff, Trump 'In Bed' with Russia
details: Rep. Gregory Meeks (D-NY) discussed a Bloomberg report on a phone call transcript between US Special Envoy Steve Witkoff and a top Putin advisor, suggesting close alignment with Russia. The conversation occurred amid ongoing Russia-Ukraine tensions, where Moscow refuses ceasefire and advances on Ukrainian fronts. This implies potential US policy shifts under Trump that undermine Ukraine's sovereignty, fostering inefficiencies in international alliances and unintended consequences like reduced self-reliance for affected nations.

title: Georgia Prosecutor Drops Trump Election Interference Case
details: On Wednesday, a Georgia prosecutor officially dropped the historic racketeering case against President Donald Trump and others for attempting to overturn the 2020 presidential election. This closes a legal effort once viewed as a major threat to Trump's political future. The dismissal highlights inefficiencies in prolonged legal battles that drain resources without resolution, potentially undermining judicial sovereignty by allowing political pressures to influence outcomes. It implies unintended consequences for self-reliance in the justice system, as reliance on partisan appointments exposes hypocrisies in pursuing accountability for election interference, ultimately weakening public trust in electoral integrity.

title: Lamont Signs Controversial H.B. 8002 Housing Bill into Law
details: Gov. Ned Lamont signed H.B. 8002 into law on November 26, 2025, after its passage in a special session, to tackle Connecticut's shortage of over 100,000 affordable housing units amid rising homelessness and rents. The bill expands fair rent commissions, removes most off-street parking mandates for small developments, and mandates town housing growth plans, following negotiations for greater local buy-in after vetoing a prior version.
